Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 06:21AM AnneW wrote: Carol, you can get a copy of your imaging report to see what they are talking about. But essentially, an U/S guided biopsy is for a solid-appearing mass. (Calcifications usually get a stereotactic.) It's common for these to be done by the intervention radiologists. You don't need a breast surgeon yet. Try to bear in mind that most biopsies are benign. Go ahead and keep your head in the sand for now. You can't control anything yet. Ask questions as you feel the need, but until you have a definitive diagnosis, you don't even really know what questions to aslk. I've had a number of these biopsies. A good radiologist numbs you well, and a good nurse is by your side for a hand-holding, and then to hold pressure on the biopsy site for about 10 minutes after. Wear a bra that will hold an ice pack, and stick with tylenol for pain (no extra bleeding potential.) Â The hardest part, as I'm sure you know, is the long wait for the biopsy report. Hang in there. Anne

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2007 05:39PM - edited Sep 30, 2007 05:39PM by AnneW Many times lumps do not show on the mammo. Both my cancers were not seen on the mammo. And calcifications do not need to be present for cancer. Any doctor who tells you not to worry should be fired. It may well be prudent based on what the U/S showed to wait three months to look for changes. But a palable lump that is not cystic-appearing by U/S should be biopsied. If I were your health care provider, I'd be sending you to a surgeon. I don't want to scare you, but you should be cautious.

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2011 07:12PM AnneW wrote: I use Neurontin for nerve pain related to a disc herniation. It works wonders for me. A friend of mine had the same pain you describe after her mastectomy and node dissection. She took Lyrica (next-generation Neurontin) and it relieved ehr pain so much. And she only needed it for a few months while the nerve was healing. There is no telling what, if any, side effects you'd experience. But if you decide to try a med under your doctor's supervision, my advice is to "start low and go slow." In other words, start at a low dose and gradually increase it. Less issues with side effects that way. Some docs, though, know little to nothing about pain management. You may have to search for one who wants to treat you with something other than narcotics--which don't really do much for nerve pain other than dumb you up a bit. Some people do okay with Lidoderm patches for a small area of nerve pain. I hope your pain will resolve on its own. Taking a med to get you over the hump is important--you do not want your body to think of pain as being "the norm." You need to break the pain cycle. That said, what's really unfortunate that post-mastectomy pain syndrome does not always resolve. Some women are left for the rest of their lives with chronic nerve pain. I hope you will not fall into that category! Good luck, Anne

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2012 07:27AM AnneW wrote: A chest CT is not the diagnostic tool of choice for breast cancer. It goes to depths below the breast. A big honkin' tumor would be seen, but maybe not a smaller one. It can give insight into lymph nodes, though. The most specific diagnostic test you can ask for is a breast MRI. Which you should have because of your implants anyway. If they can't figure out why your axillary nodes are enlarged, an MRI should be considered.

Posts.Content: AnneW wrote: I can't believe this is happening to ME. Complications do not happen to ME. I had my implant exchange a week ago on Monday. It was way more painful than I anticipated, but not in the incisions. The pain was just below my right arm pit. I had a little post-op bleeding, and thought maybe it was a seroma. By Friday, I was up to getting in some treadmill and stretching time. But certain stretches on the right side sent pain like a hot, sharp knife into my armpit and shoulder blade. It was so sudden and intense that I literally gasped and would have dropped to my knees, had I not already been on the floor. Saturday, it happened every time I stretched out my upper body. Horrible! Ice helped a little. Sunday, it was most of the day when I walked, or moved my arm. From the top of the breast to the edge of my scapula. In addition to the hot knife, there is also a dull ache and a burning sensation to the skin. I know what this is. I was hoping maybe to see the rash of herpes zoster or shingles. But I know this is post-op nerve pain/post-mastectomy syndrome. Not very common, but it certainly happens. Shit. I can't even wear my Iron Maiden post op bra due to the pain, so now I'm afraid my new girls are going to try to migrate back toward my armpits. I've worked in a pain clinic, so I know the drill. I'm calling my pain buddies for Lyrica right away. And maybe lidoderm patches. Maybe even an injection, if nipping it in the bud is the right thing to do.And then I'll call my ps and tell him what's up. I see him Wednesday for my post-op follow-up. And I have a feeling I know way more about this than he does. I'm hoping this will be short-lived. Most people get through it in a few weeks, but being in "the business", I've seen it last a long, long time. Scary. I'm pretty tough, but this is making me a baby! Has anyone had experience with this and used a good physical therapist to relieve the pain? Any other suggestions I might be overlooking? Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 04:52AM AnneW wrote: Danismom, Nerve pain is wicked. It can vary from intense "electric shocks" to a hot stabbing knife to burning to road-rash sensations. It can be intermittent or constant. Occasionally you need a pain specialist to ferret it all out for you. The problem is that the body remembers these nerve pathways, and you need to "reboot" your system, so to speak, either through massage or medications specific for nerve pain or nerve blocks. There's not often an easy answer, and not too many of our doctors really understand this (or any) type of pain. I'm not sure your pain has anything to do with the blood blisters. I hope you find relief. I can help give you some alternatives, or at least questions to ask your docs, if you wish. PM me, if you desire. Anne

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2008 06:16AM AnneW wrote: Desny, On, those niggling doubts. I had them initially 5 years ago, after my first diagnosis, but suppressed them. We were just beginning breast MRIs back then, so it was not part of my diagnostic workup. I always suspected that something "might" be going on in my "good" breast. Even when an MRI was done to check out an irregular spot a few years later, an area of low suspicion was ignored in favor of getting out some ADH in a different spot. A few years later, that ignored area was a barely palpable cancer. So, if you suspect something is lurking in the other breast, you owe it to yourself to get it checked out. Trust your inner voice. Know that MRIs do give false positives, and you may have to endure some anxiety-provoking biopsies. I really don't know why any doctor would requst a unilateral MRI. It hardly costs any extra. Good luck getting this figured out. Bongo hugs, Anne (the REAL Granny Annie. Sheesh, you gotta watch this place like a hawk for imposters and identity theives, no matter how young and gorgeous they are!)
Posts.Title: Need to see how others testing went, concerned Desny AnneW

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 01:46PM AnneW wrote: I've done both routes. My first cancer I had a lumpectomy. The second time, in the other breast, I had a bilateral mastectomy. I don't regret spending 5 extra years with my own breasts. But I did not have a disfiguring lumpectomy at the start. MY personal feeling is that if you can keep your breasts with a good cosmetic outcome, do it. But if you're going to have ONE breast removed for disease, then take them both, and get recon at the same time. Consider skin sparing/nipple sparing on the healthy breast and flap surgery for the best outcome. Best of luck. This is really a difficult decision, but you'll make the right choice for you.

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2007 06:51AM AnneW wrote: Valium is great for muscle spasms, but it is very sedating. Narcotics are very sedating for some people, too. Are you taking the pills on an as needed basis, or on a schedule? Do you need them as often as you're taking them? Can you substitute tylenol or advil between doses of narcotics and valium? Did you have expanders placed (I presume so, that's why the valium.) I found that stretching and massage by the physical therapist helped control pain. (Make sure it's okay with your doctor.) If your pain is getting better, try taking meds when you know you'll be hurting. If you're just going to be on the couch watching TV, maybe you won't need the pills. I spent a lot of time on the couch! I was taking perhaps 4-5 pain pills a day for a couple weeks. I alternated between Darvocet and Dilaudid. Neither makes me very sleepy. I didn't need the valium because my pec muscles had been botoxed and wouldn't spasm. That first week post-op is definitely a foggy time. You'll get better and need less meds, I promise! Anne

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 04:19PM AnneW wrote: So, they are doing an excisional biopsy? I am assuming that you don't know whether or not there is cancer yet? I had a similar situation 7 years ago. I asked for an excisional biopsy rather than a needle aspiration under ultrasound, because I wanted it OUT. Little did I know that the scar tissue from the biopsy (in the upper outer quadrant) would block the path for the dye and tracer for the SNB, which I was to have when the tumore was found to be malignant. And I ended up losing two levels of nodes. I didn't have the foresight at the time, nor did my surgeon try to convince me otherwise. I really put myself at risk for lymphedema because of this choice. Just throwing that out there. If you are just having an excisional biopsy, you should be fine for the party. But don't overdo with that arm. You'll need to heal without hematomas, burst suture lines, etc. Best of luck! Anne

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 06:52AM AnneW wrote: Jamie6, you sound a lot like me. I was 44 with a very well differentiated, 1 cm, node negative, hormone + Â IDC. My local onc said chemo was "up to me". My rad onc said I should definitely have chemo because of my age. (Age is not a prognostic factor!) I took it on myself to get a second opinion by a bc specialist at UCLA, who said chemo would only help about 3 out of 100 women with my type of cancer. But taking something systemic (tamoxifen or AI) was necessary. It's interesting to me how emotional and adamant some doctors get about what we should do, when they are not the specialist. Family docs, surgeons, radiation docs all weigh in with their "expert" opinions on what we should do. I guess we, as survivors, do the same, unfortunately. Everyone's got an opinion. It's just a matter of whose opinion you, the patient, value most. I'm obviously a big fan of second opinions by big-name folks, if available (probably because I got the advice I wanted to hear?) If my second bc had been found at the time of the first one (which I personally believe would have been done had breast MRI been available to me then) I would have gotten emotional and had chemo, even though that may not have been necessary...retrospect is not easy or fair at times. Anyway, anyone who is needing to make this really tough decision--really listen to the experts. Try to get your emotions out of this highly emotional topic. Look hard at the stats (though for some, stats don't bear out, unfortunately.) Understand the difference between relative risk and actual risk. Get an onc who will explain all this to you in plain terms. Even with all this, there are sleepless nights. Making the decision is the toughest part of the journey. At least, for today. best, Anne

Moist heat to the area can help, as can arnica cream. It's homeopathic, brand name Traumeel, and I have used it liberally on my bruises and surgical sites in the past. Especially recently after my mastectomies--I had some pretty gnarly bruising. Huge hematomas sometimes need to be surgically "evacuated." Your doctor would be the best judge of that. Good luck! Anne

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 09:38AM AnneW wrote: LiG, It's a hard choice. We try to keep it rational, but it is very emotional. In 2002, I had a lumpectomy and rads. Before that diagnosis, I had always said that if I got cancer, both breasts would come off and I'd be done. When faced with the reality, there was no real reason for me to do that, and I wanted to conserve my breast. I didn't have problems with radiation. No chemo. Six years later, I had a new cancer in the other breast. I chose bilateral mastectomies then. My radiated side tolerated the implant pretty well, but I had issues with scar tissue on both sides. Ultimately, I had bilateral SGAP. I kinda wish I'd done THAT from day one, the breasts look and feel so natural. But, I didn't, and I'm not one to look back with regret for what I didn't know at the time. That's just my story. What's hard is trying to make the decision. Nothing will be exactly as you planned. There's a lot of adjusting along the way. But once you make a decision that supports your values, then move forward and don't look back. You'll work it out. There will be more than a few sleepless nights along the way, but you'll get there. I wish you the best, Anne

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 04:49PM AnneW wrote: Karen, I'm so glad you are done with surgery and have started expanding already! Good luck with that. Awesome that the nodes are clear, and the invasive cancer is less than thought! I remember being obsessed with learning about chemo. At 1 cm, it wasn't necessarily "required", but I could do it if I chose to. I had people in my face to face support group tell me point blank that I was crazy NOT to. That upset me to the point that I quit the group and found my own friends who supported me and my decision process in a way I needed. I couldn't understand why in holy hell would I want to put A/C in my system and risk heart damage, when the odds were low that chemo would help me at all. I would have chosen a longer course of CMF for fewer side effects. And why was no one advising me to get the ovaries out, when that was the standard of care for early stage bc in Europe? I ultimately chose ovarian suppression (then removal) and hormonal treatment. I still got a new primary, a year after stopping AIs. Maybe it was there all along and the AIs kept it in check. My theory, but we'll never know. So, statistically, I'm a new primary in the other breast post treatment. Moot now. I don't think you sound hopeless and resigned to dying. I think you are looking for control of a terrible situation, and for validation of your values. I understand that completely. And I know there is NO guarantee that with or without chemo, the cancer may or may not recur. Stastically, your chances of overall survival are better with chemo. We don't have "designer chemo" yet--tailor made just for your tumor. EXCEPT where herceptin comes in, and that's about as designer as you can get. Back in the 60s, my mom developed Stage 111b breast cancer. Many positive nodes. She was only 39. She did a radical mastectomy and cobalt radiation--no chemo (whether or not it was even offered, I'll never know.) She lived to raise us three kids, dying of colon cancer (and I think peritoneal mets from what must have been ILC) at age 60. I miss her every day, but she DID live against the odds to raise her kids, which was her goal. Anyway, what you are going through right no is THE hardest part. Or at least it was for me. Deciding what was the right path to take in my treatment. If I had had your tumor type and size, it would have been a no-brainer, even without kids to see grow up. But I am not in your shoes. This is truly your choice. It's about as lonely a place as you can find right now. Anne
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 04:09PM AnneW wrote: With larger tumors, you can be node negative and still have some systemic migration of your cancer cells. A lot depends on the tumor grade. You're forty years old and still churning out estrogen. You have estrogen receptor positive cancer. Are you planning Lurpon on surgical menopuase as part of your treatment? My tumor was only 1 cm the first go-round. The debate raged then about chemo for me (I was 44) even with very favorable prognostic factors for my cancer (before the days of oncotype.) My second opinion doc at UCLA said no chemo was okay as long as I did hormonals as a systemic treatment. So, after lumpectomy and rads, I tried Tamoxifen, had problems with it, then ultimately had the ovaries out and went on Femara. Fast forward 6 years, and there's a new cancer in the other breast. I don't regret not taking chemo--not at all--but it ws scary and sobering. My story will not be your story. Your story will not be anyone else's. You and your docs need to make a decision based on many factors. Surely they've plugged your numbers into Adjuvant! and seen what your risk of recurrence is with 3 cm mass and Her2+, regardless of nodes. The best advice I can give is to research the heck out of your options, then examine your value system. Then, make a decision and don't look back with regrets if your cancer recurs or metastisizes. What makes you think there is something "strange" going on? Anne

I had the wire insertion (I actually passed out--and here I am a nurse who is fazed by nothing! I blame the resident who was struggling to get the wire in place!) Anyway, my excisional was clear. Four years later I did have a 1 cm ILC removed in that breast, but nowhere near the excision site. As I understand it, ALH is just a "marker" for a problem that may or may not happen. The reason they do the excisional is that it may be "the tip of the iceberg." In about 7% of the cases, if I recall. My radiologists and oncologist were pretty adamant about getting the surgery done. Could you handle the insecurity that goes with "wait and see"? Or would every twinge be a cancer fear? Explore how you feel, and make your decision based on that. Good luck, Anne

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 09:42PM AnneW wrote: karen, This is a very emotional time right now. You're trying to get information, make life-changing decisions when you don't have enough data to make a good one, convince people you are okay, take care of your family, work--all when you really just want to curl up in a ball and sob. But, you DO have time. Take a deep breath. Start learning all you can--not just by asking us what we've been through (though that does have its place!) but by reading. Get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book. It's the bible for us. Breast conservation (lumpectomy and radiation) is usually encouraged, but it's truly your choice. I'm one who gladly went that route, and had 5 more years to live with my breasts till I got a new cancer last month. Now both breasts are gone and I'm "under construction." Would I have done it any differently? No, I don't think so, but it's not really a fair question in hindsight. You just have to make a decision and not look back with the "what ifs." I hope your cancer is for sure Stage 1 and no other treatment than hormonals will be needed. Till you get the node/s out and the margins clear, and the estrogen receptors back, you'll not know for sure. Just take your time to get your ducks in a row. Make your decision based on information, not just fear. (And yes, some breast cells can be left behind after a mastectomy. Whether or not these will ever become cancerous is not known. And Stage 1 tumors can metastasize at some point in your life, though it's not as likely. You will, I'm afraid, never be free and clear of cancer. It will always be in the back of your mind. But, you CAN keep living your life and be happy and move forward.) Hope this doesn't overwhelm you. hang in there. Anne

My body has changed in ways I don't like. My brain doesn't feel as sharp. But I only have mild hot flashes. I guess it just is what it is. And it was going to happen one way or the other. Sometimes I feel I did better by getting all over with quickly, as opposed to some of my friends who just seem to linger in the perimenopausal pergutory! Effexor helped with my hot flashes and mood stuff initially. Now I use low-dose Zoloft. Physical recovery from the laparoscopy was about 2 weeks. I think the worst thing has been the vaginal dryness, but I use the FemRing for that. Thank god for my FemRing. Good luck. Hopefully you'll sail through. Anne

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 09:54PM - edited Apr 11, 2008 09:56PM by AnneW This article has a really interesting paragraph that pertains to this issue, and I've tried to highlight it in bold. In a nutshell, there's a benign condition called "proliferative" breast disease which can be a prelude to cancer. This may explain mixed tumor types. Estrogen Linked to Benign Breast Lumps April 09, 2008 WASHINGTON - Add another risk to hormone therapy after menopause: Benign breast lumps. One type of hormone therapy - estrogen plus progestin - already is well-known to increase the risk of breast cancer. But a major study of women able to use estrogen alone didn't find that link. Tuesday, researchers reported a new wrinkle: Those estrogen-only users doubled their chances of getting non-cancerous breast lumps. That's a concern not only because of the extra biopsies and worry those lumps cause, but because a particular type - called benign proliferative breast disease - is suspected of being a first step toward developing cancer 10 years or so later. About one in five women undergo a breast biopsy within a decade of starting annual mammograms, and most are of those abnormalities turn out to be benign. Yet under a microscope, there are different types, from simple fluid-filled cysts to what's called proliferative breast disease because it's made of growing cells. The latest work, published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, re-examines data from the landmark Women's Health Initiative that found a variety of health risks from long-term hormone therapy. Only women who have undergone hysterectomies are able to use estrogen- only therapy, and the WHI originally included more than 10,000 of those women, who were given either estrogen or a dummy drug and tracked for about seven years. Now, a team led by Dr. Tom Rohan of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York has reviewed breast biopsies done on those women - and identified 232 cases of benign proliferative breast disease. Women given the estrogen-only therapy had twice the risk of developing these abnormalities compared with women given a placebo. WHI participants are still being tracked, allowing scientists to eventually tell if the benign breast problems were a signal of more trouble to come, Rohan concluded.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 12:11PM AnneW wrote: A diagnostic mammo for a documented breast lump should be covered by insurance, regardless of one's age. It is no longer a routine screening. When the palpable lump is a part of your imaging histroy, the radiologist always addresses it in one way or another. (or at least s/he should!) If no corresponding mass was seen on mammo, the almost always classify you with a high BIRADS score, meaning further follow-up is indicated. They do that to cover their butts, but that's exactly what the person who ordered your mammo in the first place should do. In other words, if you you have a palpable mass not seen on mammo, then the radiologist should recommend either U/S or MRI. If they don't the person who felt your lump and ordered the mammo is obligated to do a further work up, or refer you to a surgeon. Telling a woman with a lump to "wait a few months" when no other work up has been done is, to ME, negligent. But, many women who have been told to get rechecked in 6 months don't come back for a year or more, and are mad because now they have a higher stage cancer. Bottom line, mammos are NOT definitive. The media plays them up way too much as a way to "catch" cancer early. For every woman who had her cancer diagnosed by mammogram, there's another who did not.

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 05:11AM AnneW wrote: You're stage 1. Guidelines still support lumpectomy with rads, followed by a hormone blocker, if you're ER+. If you're ER-, you can still have lumpectomy and rads, but will be urged to do chemo. Have you had the ONCOtype Dx done to see your risk of recurrence? That wasn't available when I had my first bc at age 44. I was stage 1, grade 1. My local onc siad chemo was "up to me." My rads onc said I should have it "because of my age" (though that is not one of the NCI's prognostic indicators.) I had a second opinion at a major med center because I was so confused. He said put a hundred women in a room with my kind of cancer, and chemo would help 3 of them. As long as I did tamoxifen or an AI (with ovarian suppression) he wouldn't recommend chemo. It was a lonely time in my head while I was sorting all this out and making decisions that may affect the rest of my life. Ultimately, I went with my second opinion doc and never looked back. Even with a new primary six years later, I had no regrets about doing what I did. If you do "have to have" chemo, you'll get through it. We'll be here with you every step of the way, if you desire. I wish you the best, Anne

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 12:00PM AnneW wrote: I don't think it's so much a functin of the orientation of the incision but how much care was taken to preserve the nerves in the area. And just because the external incision is horizontal, it doesn't mean the inner layers were dissected that way. I had a horizontal incision 10 years ago, with aÂ two levelÂ axillary dissection. I had the typical brachial plexus trauma--numbness along the back of my arm, a little cording initially. But no LE and full range of motion in no time. My scars tend to heal thickly. They stay red and raised for a long time. A vertical scar can be pulled too tightly, the same as a horizontal one, and give a bunched up appearance. You should heal fine. Your risk of LE is the same regardless of scar orientation. Mobilizing the scar area gently through massage and motion should help you get back to your activities in a timely manner. (And sometimes surgeons don't know exactly what approach they will take till they get to the OR.) Concentrate on taking care of yourself--sounds like you're in good hands--and here's hoping you'll heal just fine!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2008 11:30AM AnneW wrote: Hello, Heidi, Regardless of any of our own stories, this is a decision that is yours alone to make. Any "happy endings" on our part do not equate to your situation, as I'm sure you know. It's a matter of trusting your gut and moving forward. Looking back later if a recurrence happens serves no useful purpose. If you're the type who second-guesses things, then make your decision based on that. I had a lumpectomy and rads. Did just fine, with my very dense breasts, till I developed a new primary in the other breast. Then I had both removed. While I toyed with the idea of having both removed with my first cancer (despite the cancer being very small and well-differentiated), I was ultimately glad I got to "keep" my breasts for the next 5-6 years. Dense breasts do make imaging a little harder. Dense breasts do not cause cancer. I'm not sure I would amputate a breast because it's dense. Multi-focal disease, though, in a dense breast would cause me to ponder and really figure out what my fears and values were. Which is where you are right now. Good luck with this highly personal, intensely difficult choice. Anne

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 10:00PM AnneW wrote: Hey, all, another nurse chiming in here! I started as a CNA 30 years ago while in my BSN program. Went into the Air Force for a few years (82-86) but didn't have a flying assignment, though I wentÂ to flight nurse school. Got my MSN in 1991 and have been a family nurse practitioner ever since. I have the luxury of working part time at a college health clinic. I love my job and the people I work with. Both times with my cancers I've been able to take off whatever time I need. A big part of that is having a wonderful, supportive husband. I never felt I had to push for info as a patient. In fact, I have felt like I've gotten special treatment and understanding as being "one of them". My docs and NPs respond to me quickly. I'm taken seriously with my concerns and questions about the literature. And no one assumes that I know everything. I feel quite fortunate in that respect of my care. I do feel that most primary care providers know very little about breast cancer. What I knew before I was first diagnosed, I ahd learned from seeing my mom go through it. At one point I considered writing a book for PCPs about breast cancer basics. Then I got tired of researching, so I moved on to more fun things like hiking, biking, and climbing. Initially I felt the need to be the "expert"--now, I don't. I know there are a few more nurses out here. I'm sure they'll check in soon. Anne

She opted for a mastectomy, no reconstruction, no chemo (small tumor, ER-, node -) She and her oncologist figured she would not die from breast cancer--heart disease is still her worst enemy at that age. Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 08:13AM AnneW wrote: Sentinal node indicates the first node in the path that would be filtering the cancer cells. Sometimes the dye and tracer show multiple nodes that take up the stuff equally, and the surgeon will remove the bunch. Other times, there may be a true, single sentinal node, but the surgeon gets several close by to be on the safe side. Other surgeons see the sentinal, trust that it's truly the first in line, and take only that one node. So, having a group of nodes removed doesn't mean anything yet. It won't change the fact that you'll have chemo. Multiple positive nodes might mean rads, but you will deal with that if you have to. Adequate treatment trumps reconstruction. So, try not to let the mind rush to the dark corners (yeah, right, I'm good at saying that, but I've been there, too!) Here's hoping they're free and clear! Anne

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 07:48AM AnneW wrote: A single cancer cell can only be seen under exact staining and magnification techniques in the lab. The dye and isotopes are, as Joni said, to determine which nodes drain the breast first. Those (or that) node would be the logical filter for any cancer, and it's only necessary to take that node. With my first cancer, the SNB didn't "take" because I had had an excisional biopsy first, and scar tissue blocked the path of the dye and isotopes. So, I lost two levels of nodes. Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 09:55PM AnneW wrote: Randie, I'm so sorry it's cancer. But now that you know it's IDC, you have time to breathe, research your options, and get professional opinions (and ours, too! We've got 'em!) Don't rush into a surgery you're not sure about. If you want a mastectomy, fine, maybe he's your man. But then what about reconstruction? Immediate recon means one less surgery, but you need to get with a plastic surgeon for that, and that can take a little time to coordinate. Even with immediate recon, you generally don't need 5 days in the hospital (unless it's the advanced recon like DIEP--and I'm certain your surgeon doesn't do that!) Don't be rushed!! Get another surgical opinion. Make sure your surgeon is proficient with the sentinal node biopsy procedure. Get your list of questions together. Now's the time to mobilize your resources, not to make hasty decisions. Again, I'm so sorry that you're joining our club. But we're here to help guide you through the craziness. We've all been there. Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 10:13AM AnneW wrote: I don't know that I would have had an elective surgery to try to "fix" the nerve pain I had. But since I had a very skilled microvascular surgeon doing my new recon, I figured it didn't hurt to ask her to examine that area closely. (My surgeon is Dr. Marga Massey. I had to travel to Charleston, SC to have the surgery. I live in CO.) Anyway, she marked my skin in the area of the nerve and was able to find it and fix it. Some of the discomfort has returned as the nerve regrew over these past 8 months. But it's very superficial and I rarely feel it when I wear a bra. I can't stress enough finding some sort of pain management that works. Chronic pain is hard to treat. It's best to get aggressive with PMPS from the outset so the body doesn't think this pain is the "norm." A nerve block may be effective, too, if done by a skilled, board certified pain specialist. Deep tissue massage always made my pain worse. My PT (who is also an LE specialist) did very light massage to reduce scar tissue, but I can't say it helped much. The meds were all that helped me. The thing with Neurontin is that sometimes you have to take really high doses to achieve the goal. And, in CO now, there's medical marijuana!! Not that's anything I'd ever want (I don't think!) but it's an interesting proposition. (Here in Boulder, there's a pot shop on every corner!) Take care, all, Anne

Posts.Content: AnneW wrote: I saw both my breast and plastic surgeons this week, and if they can ever get their schedules coordinated, I'll know just when we're going to do this! After much studying and talking, I've decided to go with the bilateral mastectomies with immediate expander/implant reconstruction. For those who may not know, I had IDC 5 years ago on the left, with lumpectomy and rads. Now I have ILC on the right. My girls have gone bad, so to speak, so it's time for new ones. In talking with the plastics guy (whom I dearly love and used to work with several years ago) we agree that I'm far too active for any muscle-related flap. And when you get right down to it, I probably don't have enough fat for a bilateral DIEP or GAP. Despite me being heavier than I've ever been (thanks, menopause!) I still don't have much fat. Except on my thighs!!! So, we're going for the implants, which he feels pretty sure will be successful, despite my previous rads. Were it not for the tattoos, he'd never have known I'd had rads. Of course, we can't really tell how the skin and muscle will respond till we do it. I'm intrigued by the procedures they will be using. The surgeon uses a "pain buster" post-op--a thin tube going into each breast area, with a continuous pumping of marcaine/bupivicaine (numbing medicines) for about 5 days (similar to what they use in joint replacement surgery now.) And the plastics guy uses Alloderm (yay!) PLUS Botox to paralyze the pectoral muscle to let it accept the implants without as much spasm. Botox takes about 3 months to wear off. I told him that if he had a little bit left in the vial, not to waste it. I have a wrinkle up near my forehead that drives me crazy... So, after that comes recovery. I have a postsurgery cami on order. Wondering how long before I can drive, exercise, etc, but I realize that's putting the cart before the horse. I need to be patient, I know. Now, all I need is the date. Anne 2002 IDC stage 1, grade 1, rads & AI Dx 9/18/2007, ILC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: AnneW wrote: Another member and I have been sharing experiences via PM, and I thought this topic should come to the forefront, given all the infections and super-bugs, etc. Hospitals are not the cleanest of places. Most post-op infections are nosocomial (meaning hospital-induced.) We can't control the sterility and techniques in the OR, but we CAN control what goes on around us in a hospital room. Make sure there's a lot of hand sanitizer available--and that everyone who enters the room uses it. Usually there's a dispenser placed near the sink, but you may want your own bottle on your bedside table. Before anyone touches you, ask them politely to cleanse first. (And after, is ideal for all the patients they come in contact with after you!) Visitors need to be clean. You need to be clean. Before surgery, shower a couple times with an antiseptic soap like Hibiclens. You can get it at a drug store. I'll be doing this starting two or three days before my surgery. Feel free to ask the pre-op folks how they intend to prevent infection while you're in the OR. Feel free to remind your surgeon to wash up or use sanitizer before s/he comes in to check your dressings and drains. In fact, insist on it. They won't be offended. They don't want any infections on their watch, believe me. Anyone else have suggestions for keeping clean and safe while in the hospital? Or while in the home recovering? Anne 2002 IDC stage 1, grade 1, rads & AI Dx 9/18/2007, ILC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

I chose a lumpectomy and radiation and hormone treatment, and lived happily ever after--for about 6 years. Then developed a new cancer in the other breast. Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 10:18AM AnneW wrote: I think your idea is fabulous, whippetmom & deeds! Call it the BCO Project. I'd love to help out, having been here for 7 years--I've seen a lot, and experienced a lot. Re the PMPS--it is so very "for real" but the surgeons don't really acknowledge it because it implies a less than perfect outcome on their part. And I know so many doctors who believe that educating you about potential bad outcomes means that with every little twinge we'll be calling them in panic mode. When really, it's the exact opposite! One reason to aggressively treat neuropathic pain like PMPS is because the body/brain will start to recognize pain as the norm. By then, it's too late. Like a computer, you need to "reboot" the system. Lyrica or Neurontin with Clonazepam or Cymbalta help do that. I had severe nerve pain after my implant exhange--down my side initially, then into my armpit and shoulder blade when I stretched and rotated my body. Horrific! My PS just seemed befuddled. I got to a pain specialist immediately and got on treatment. (I used to work for the pain clinic, so I knew what to do!) The meds helped relieve the pain, but my "cure" was when I got the implants out and had flap surgery. My new PS untethered that nerve from the scar tissue that had built up, and I was able to get off meds. Scar tissue was the result, but I agree it didn't START that way! It was interoperative trauma. I suppose that even if I had been advised of this potential, but rare, issue, I would have gone ahead with the surgery. And if I had been given a big list of everything that could possibly go wrong, I wouldn't remember half of it. But it would have been nice to have some resources to refer to when it DID occur, so I wouldn't have felt all alone in my pain. So, how do we limit it to 25?? There are so many potential issues, depending on what the category is. Some of us may focus on reconstruction. Others may want to take up chemo, rads, LE...there are many women here with lots to say, things that can help so many others. I see more than a PDF or tear sheet. We've got ourselves a book! Anne

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 10:19PM AnneW wrote: A quick word about massage therapists...I use a guy, and have no qualms about being naked under the sheets. But it's MY job to tell him to back off the pressure, or add more, depending on what feels good (or bad!) to me. He can't read my mind, but is certainly in tune to when I wince. TuffyBuffy, I'm not sure a class action lawsuit will get you anywhere. Is there a defective product? No. These are unusual post-op complications. I worked in a pain clinic once, and saw all sorts of pain syndromes following surgeries, from bunionectomies to knee scopes to failed back surgeries to hernia repairs. Any time an incision is made, nerves get injured. Why some people have worse outcomes than others is the great unknown. I agree we should all be told of the potential risks. But, if you were told that your mastectomy could result in a 1% (or whatever the going # is) chance that you'd be left with chronic pain, what would you do? I'd still have the surgery...I DID have the surgery. I got pain. I wish there were answers. Educating docs is a step in the right direction. Anne

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 09:05PM AnneW wrote: Yes, indeed, what must do what feels right to us. For some it's a lumpectomy, for others it'sÂ  bilateral mastectomies. None of it guarantees the cancer is gone forever. Recurrences happen in scars, the skin, the amputated breast area, in the remaining breast tissue... And, you don't know what you'll do till you face it. Before cancer, I would say, almost cavalierly, that if I got cancer, I'd just get the breasts off and go with implants. When actually diagnosed, I heard, "We can conserve your breast" and it made perfect sense to me. And I kept my breasts for another 5 years. What worked for me may not work for anyone else. Mindy, I hate that you are struggling with money and other support. No one should have to choose chemo just for the financial aid! (Please don't if you don't physically have to.) Is your tumor small enough to get by with surgery and then hormonals? A mastectomy and then Tamoxifen or an AI may be cheaper in the long run than a lumpectomy, radiation, and then meds... Is there a social worker at your hospital, or a breast cancer facilitator, who can help you look at the numbers and how your particular situation plays out? Anne

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2008 09:50PM AnneW wrote: You've been through a lot, Jody! Radiation should decrease your chance of recurrence. But it may also result in further shrinkage of the breast. After that, if another cancer develops, you may have a more difficult time with certain types of reconstruction, if you choose to go that route (and I imagine, at your age, you would!) My advice is this: really figure out what you can live with (or without). If you're the type who will worry endlessly about a recurrence, strongly consider the mastectomy. If you're the type who makes solid decisions and doesn't second-guess yourself, you may want to conserve your breast. I had a lumpectomy and rads at 44. Then at 50 got a new cancer and had both removed. Even knowing then what I know now, I'm glad I had my real breasts for another 5+ years. It's by no means an easy decision--one that only you can make. Anne

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 07:16PM AnneW wrote: Hmmm. I'm of mixed feelings about scans without symptoms. First, they are very anxiety-provoking and often produce false positives. Second, yes, they are expensive. Regardless of HMO or PPO, as medical costs rise, so does your premium and out-of-pocket expense. Third, early scans generally don't improve statistical overall survival. That said, and I'm sure there are folks who will vehemently disagree with me and give me lots of personal experiences that I totally respect and understand, scans obviously DO have a role in cancer management. As do certain lab tests. I remember when my mom had breast cancer in the late 60s--every year after that for ages she had her yearly bone scan, liver-spleen scan, and chest x-ray. Now, we wait till there are symptoms to check for mets, as there is no early detection of mets. On the other hand, some people (but this is not the norm) have more extensive disease at the time of diagnosis. And I think that it's because it's NOT the norm that the scans are not done routinely. And, the results of the scans may not impact the treatment course. One last word about fabricating symptoms in order to get a scan...DON'T. It's fraud. And how can you build a partnership relationship with your provider if you're not telling the truth? You're way better off stating your case and why you want a scan honestly. I'll stop being devil's advocate for now. I may have said things that people don't want to hear, but I'll stand behind why I say them. Anne

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 10:20PM AnneW wrote: Yes, always ask about them, and find out your oncologist's philosophy about them. Have an understanding of when they'll be ordered without question. Make sure you know your insurance company's policy of what it covers automatically and what needs prior authorization, etc. My insurance won't do a breast MRI or PET without auth, and it can't be a "screening" tool (so it needs a specific diagnosis code.) Understanding this technical stuff up front may save some headaches unless you have a "Cadillac Plan" that covers anything,regardless. Anne

The world just seemed too beautiful--green hills, sparkling blue ocean, cloudless sky--how dare life be so gorgeous when I had effing cancer?? This go-round, only a few tears, and a determination to move forward as best I can. There's been a lot of water under this bridge for me. Stay here. Take a break if you need to. I was gone for about a year, before cancer brought me back. Do what's right for you. And knowing you, turning off the damned computer may be the best thing you can do for a while. You are a goreous, intelligent woman who has made her life through controlling variables. And your up against a beast who laughs in your face. Who doesn't melt at camel breath. Your brain finally admitted what your heart knew, and it broke you down. BUT--it didn't break your spirit, my dear. You've got tons of that, and we need to be blessed by it. But only on your terms. What a club we have here. We have our theme song ("Hotel California"), now we need our secret handshake, our secret password, and maybe our own clan's tatoo (I vote against pink ribbons--too obvious!) Maybe a camel, in honor of our favorite gal? (One hump or two? And are those humps real, or reconstructed? LOL!) Okay, enough from me. I'm glad you're not leaving for good. At first I thought we had evil people here again, attacking through pm's. Glad to see it was just reality kicking your ass. Expect it to happen again, and kick back. I love ya, girlfriend. And all my sisters here. Anne

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 10:15AM AnneW wrote: Hello, ladies. I've been AWOL for a while, but I haven't stopped thinking about you all. I'm busy with work and getting ready for big big big surgery May 19. I'm going to Charleston to have my implants removed and then a simultaneous bilateral SGAP reconstruction. I'm blessed to have really good insurance that didn't even blink when getting it approved. And blessed to have a surgeon who takes what TriCare pays, Which to me, isn't nearly enough. I think my current PS has "fired" me, but I don't know for sure. He doesn't believe I need this surgery. Granted his handiwork looks good, but feels awful. He is at a loss as to why I'm uncomfortable, and is the analytical type who wants to know WHY something is broken before trying to fix it. reasonable, but not always possible. He sent me to his partner for an opinion about my pain (I had already made up my mind I was going to do the GAP surgery by then) and she and I had a total disconnect in communication. She kept telling me things that were not true about this GAP surgery (she hasn't done any herself, and I've done my research)--and I was saying, "No, you're wrong," and she kept saying "You're not listening to me!." Sheesh. I was so frustrated I nearly cried. I thought I was going to need their support for my insurance approval. (I didn't, ultimately!) I wrote a letter to my PS explaining my frustration, owning my own part of it--wanting them to say what I wanted to hear. Explained that I wasn't trying to burn bridges, that I respected his work and all he's done for me, but that I think the GAP surgery is best. I needed to get a local doc to help me post-op with a check up and drain removals. I asked him and his nurse three times via email and voice mail if they'd help, and there's been nothing but silence. Oh well. My breast surgeon, however, is more than happy to be there for me, even though I haven't seen her in a year and a half. ANYway, it's been a ride, and I've got a lot ahead of me. I found this affirmation today that resonated with me, and I want to share it with you all. Thanks for being here! May today there be peace within. May you trust that you are exactly where you are meant to be. May you not forget the infinite possibilities that are born of faith in yourself and others. May you use the gifts that you have received, and pass on the love that has been given to you. May you be content with yourself just the way you are. Let this knowledge settle into your bones, and allow your soul the freedom to sing, dance, praise and love. It is there for each and every one of us. Anne

A friend of mine took me to lunch today. He's like a little brother to me, a dear, sweet guy who my hubby and I have seen through a decade of relationships. This means we get to know the girlfriends well, develop strong ties, get lots of stories, then they break up. I usually stay friends with them. But apparently I have said a few things around the new (and I think permanent) girl that were insensitive, and most likely I did overstep my boundaries, unintentionally. So, he wanted to talk to me about it, about her insecurity, etc. Normally, I would have no problem with this, I would be rational and understanding, and contrite. And I guess I was, but I started crying and just couldn't stop. Poor guy, he just held my hand. He reached to hug me, and I spilled my ice water, which did provide for some needed comic relief. I was able then, to figure out what was really going on...I had just gotten back from a quick visit with my PS...I have not once cried about losing my breasts and having to deal with this cancer for a second time. Why it came out now, I'm not sure, but it sure needs to come, and I'm tearing up again as I write this. Wow, I didn't realize I had it so buried. I'm pretty much a stoic person, do what you got to do and move forward. And now, I'm stopped in my tracks. Interestingly, this tearful meltdown coincides with stopping my Zoloft. I had been feeling so darn good lately (except for this damned nerve pain) that I thought maybe I didn't need the med any more. And maybe I don't. But now I feel a deep gash in my psyche that I didn't have to acknowledge before. Just when you think you're moving on, reality smacks you down a bit. But, true to form, I'll lick my wounds for a day or so, then jump back in with both feet. And restart that Zoloft. I think my seratonin needs it. I don't know what I would do without you ladies to share this with. Anne

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2008 07:44AM AnneW wrote: I am so sorry you all are going through this. You do have choices, though. I presume she had a sentinal node biopsy with her excision? One option is doing a mastectomy but not taking any more nodes. It's the node dissection that is so painful to recover from.Â  I guess you need to have the discussion about risks vs benefits. If she isn't going to have chemo at her age, then why bother taking out all the nodes. Do the doctors expect this cancer to be what ultimately causes her death, or do they think she's got a greater chance of dying from natural causes, heart diease, etc? Will the extended anesthesia time put her at risk for pneumonia? Or is she otherwise a healthy, active 92 year old who may bounce back fast from surgery? There are many considerations here. It's just not easy to address some of them. But as you read and learn and find out what your mom really wants, it will become clearer. I envy you having your mom still. Mine died of cancer at age 60. What I'd give to have her now, twenty years later... You'll do the right thing, and your mom will guide that decision. Keep us posted, please. Anne

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2008 06:27AM AnneW wrote: Hey, Otter, A couple concerns I have here involve the mammogram clinic. Where I go, I have to fill out a lengthy form, and one question on it is about new lumps or palpable things. Because if there's a palpable mass, they'll do a diagnostic mammo. And if that's inconclusive, they automatically get an ultrasound. Or, at the minimum, the radiologists put a "disclaimer" at the end of the mammo report, saying that if the mammo is negative and a lump is felt, the follow up should include such-and-such. Which the docs should note and follow. I had a similar issue a couple years ago. I had a breast MRI (for a problem with my "good" breast--calcifications.) The MRI should "an area of low suspicion" in a spot that was not near where the calcs were. It recommended a follow-up U/S in 6 months. Well, I had a large excision on the clacs--benign--and that was the end of that.Â  Four years later, that un-followed-up on area was where my second breast cancer lurked. I don't blame anyone for this oversight. I got to keep my breasts a lot longer. But I consider it MY job to keep up on that stuff, so now I keep copies of everything and actually review them from time to time... We must be our own advocates. Good luck with the biopsy, Anne

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 11:06PM AnneW wrote: Part two of the Bear Adventure: I left this morning to go work out. Locked the patio door to the deck, figured that would suffice. I came home in the afternoon to a mess in the kitchen, the slider door off its track, the trim around the door jamb and lock shattered, and my freezer drawer wide open. Damn bear! He definitely has a sweet tooth. He ate a new jar of peanut butter, a stuck of butter, a loaf of bread, and bag full of frozen pine nuts, and two boxes of ice cream sandwiches! Dirt was everywhere, and the kitties were freaked out. I called the Dept of Wildlife again, and a man came out tonight to set up a pepper spray device, with a rag soaked in honey and bacon grease for bait. We also got some rubber buckshot for our 12 gauge shotgun, in case we get a close look. The DOW guy kind of chastised us for having any doors open at all (crap, it's summer, and hot, and we don't have A/C in the mountains!) But this bear broke down a locked door! I hope this scare tactic works. I'd hate for them to have to trap it and kill it. But it's getting aggressive. This happened to our neighbor two years ago. DOW set a trap. The bear recognized it (we think) and that was the last of the trouble. I'm thinking about borrowing a friend's dog for a while. Maybe that would be enough threat. He's a good sized black bear--I'd guess about 250 pounds. I couldn't tell if he's been tagged as a "relocated offender" or not. DOW had to put down a bear in town yesterday, and they got all kinds of bad press and stuff. Boulder is unique in wanting to protect wildlife over people, unless it's in their back yard. That's why town is overrun with plague-infested pririe dogs."They're so cute!" Hmph. Just plain rodents, to me. Anyway, I hope this does the trick. And we'll have to leave deck doors completely shut for a while, not just propped open even a little. Crap. Well, now thatÂ all the snacks are out of the house, I should have no excuse for healthier living and losing a pound or two! To be continued... Anne

Karen, high potassium levels could be from supplements, but I assume they've checked his kidneys? Renal failure can do some of this, too. Ulla, did you just get your first Zoladex? It stops the ovaries, but sometimes there's extra tissue in our uterus to be shed when we don't ovulate. For some, it's just a trickle. For others, it's like the floodgates opened. Sue, my dear, and Ulla, and anyone else who finds herself in a dark place, it DOES get better. You have been through hell, and your brain chemistry is totally whacked. Seriously, get on medication to correct this imbalance. You'd do it for any other part of your body! You deserve to feel better! You can't kick bootface till you're mentally strong. By the way, being a latecomer of sorts to this delightful thread, can you tell me the origin of BOOTFACE? Anne

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2008 10:26AM AnneW wrote: What a house, Karen! So open and airy and light--it has a happy feel to it. Can't wait to see how you decorate all that open space. And those windows! My goodness! We just spent $250 on window cleaning. We have tons of windows, and they are very high, too (A-frame mountain home) so we splurge and let the pros clean them! Sue, I'm wondering if your immune system is so whacked that you have something really funky going on. You ache in muscles and joints, PLUS your joints are swollen?? Make sure the quacky docs draw some blood for an arthritis panel/ lupus panel along with complete blood counts and ESR (also known as sed rate,Â which shows generalized inflammation.) Increase the anti-depressant dose? Chronic (and acute) pain deplete the seratonin even more, so it may seem like the med's not working. Were you on constant doses of steroids during treatment, or just when you had the chemo? Steroid withdrawl can mimic a lot of what you're going through, but it's been 6 weeks, so maybe that's not it. Your body ain't too happy right now, huh? I'm sorry you're suffering like this. Time for me to leave this computer alone and go clean cupboards, so I can restock them. A big bunch of hubby's clan is coming in for the week. I know they'll be helpful once there's here, but in the meantime I must buy groceries, clean the house, wash the towels that have been in storage for ages...plus work, and get in my exercise (which I will NOT push to the side, like usual. This is for ME, dammit!) And, of course, hubby is out of town on business till the day his family starts arriving. Deep breath, Annie! I said I wouldn't get stressed, but I know I am a bit. Oh, well, to the kitchen I go! Have a great day, y'all! Anne
